11/So the NRA really only helped obtain their desired outcome in 3 of 138 races. Their win-rate was 2.2%.
10/Of these 15 races only 3 were successful: supporting Jeff Flake (R-AZ) and Orrin Hatch (R-UT), and opposing Richard Lugar (R-IN).
9/So really there were only 15 races on which the NRA was a real player.
8/Here's more: out of the remaining 131 races, the NRA spent less than $100,000 in 116 and had a negligible effect on these races.
7/Here's why: out of the 138 candidates, the NRA took credit for 7 electoral victories in races in which it spent under $100.
6/But 52% is make-believe.
5/In 2012, the NRA donated money to 138 candidates, and says it won 72 races, yielding a win-rate of 52%.
4/That’s the number of races in which the NRA’s desired outcome was achieved, divided by the number of races it was financially involved in.
3/Chapter 2: In order to convey its alleged success in influencing electoral outcomes, the NRA uses a measurement called a win-rate.
